front.title: A Digital Emblem for Protected Humanitarian Efforts

author.organization: Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Lab

abstract.t: In the physical realm, the Red Cross, Red Crescent, and Red Crystal signify protections under International Humanitarian Law. Today, a vast majority of humanitarian organizations rely on Internet connectivity to carry out their mission. This document describes a digital version of the protective emblem that will provide robust signals to digital actors of a resources protection under International Humanitarian Law.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: In the physical realm, the Red Cross, Red Crescent, and Red Crystal signify protections under International Humanitarian Law. Today, a vast majority of humanitarian organizations rely on Internet connectivity to carry out their mission. This document describes a digital version of the protective emblem that will provide robust signals to digital actors of a resources protection under International Humanitarian Law.

Protecting digital assets requires a number of critical capabilities:
The protected status is visible The signal of protection comes from a trusted entity The signal of protection cannot be modified by third parties The querying of the protective status of an entity does not adversely affect that entity.

This document describes a protocol for the creation and publication of a digital emblem utilizing the Domain Name System (DNS) global infrastructure. This protocol is modeled after Sender Policy Framework (SPF) that is utilized to authorize e-mail senders within a domain .
The capitalized key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Protocol Overview
section.t: The objective of the protocol is to allow humanitarian organizations to signal that digital assets are use to fulfill its mission and therefore are entitled to protection from attack under IHL. These assets include both physical and virtual resources (servers, virtual machines, etc.) and network traffic associated with those resources. This is accomplished by associating a digital emblem attribute with the DNS domain name, or sub-domain, and/or with the IP address(es) associated with those resource(s).
The following sub-sections describe the three parties associated with the digital emblem and their roles in creating an emblem.

section.title: Approvers
section.t: An Approver is an organization empowered to authorize the use of the emblem. Each member of the United Nations has an identified organization tasked with fulfilling this role. All Approvers, or an organization operating on their behalf, generate and maintain digital signing credentials in TLSA records published in the DNS (Section ). An Approver receives requests for use of the digital emblem from Requestors. If the request satisfies all necessary requirements, the Approver generates the necessary cryptographic material and returns it to the Requestor (Section ).

section.title: Requestors
section.t: A Requestor is any organization wishing to use the digital emblem to protect the digital assets associated with its humanitarian mission. The Requestor sends the necessary DNS resource information to an Approver. If the Approver approves the use of the digital emblem for the identified resources, the Requestor publishes the returned cryptographic material in a Digital Emblem Record (Section ).

section.title: Observers
section.t: An Observer is any entity that wishes to assess the claim of protection under the digital emblem. This is accomplished by obtaining both the Digital Emblem Record associated with a target system (domain name or IP address) published by the Requestor and the signing certificate associated with the Approver that is identified in the Digital Emblem Record. An Observer then uses the key material in the signing certificate to verify the cryptographic material published in the target's Digital Emblem Record (Section ).

section.title: Approver Credentials
section.t: Approvers generate, publish, and maintain valid digital signing certificates for attesting to Digital Emblem Records. These signing certificates MUST be published in the DNS via DNS-based Authentication of Named Entities (DANE) TLSA Record .

All TLSA records MUST be protected by DNS Security Extensions (DNSSEC) .

section.title: Approver Generated Material
section.t: Once an Approver has deemed a request to be satisfactory, it generates two pieces of cryptographic material. First, the Approver generates a pseudo-random number (i.e., nonce) using a secure random number generator (TBD: need additional details on the characteristics of the nonce). Second, the Approver generates a digital signature (FIPS.186-5?) using its private key associated with its signing certificate (published in a DNS TLSA record) over the nonce and the identifying material (e.g., domain name) provided by the Requestor.
After generating the above material, the Approver returns the nonce, the digital signature, and a reference to its DNS TLSA record containing the corresponding signing certificate.

section.title: Digital Emblem Record
section.t: A Digital Emblem Record (DER) is a DNS record that declares that a host is protected under IHL. The DER is expressed as a single string of text found in the RDATA of a single DNS TXT resource record. Multiple DER records MAY exist for the same name. This occurs if the Requestor has received authorization from multiple Approvers. Each DER is placed in the DNS tree at the owner name to which it pertains. Given that TXT records serve multiple purposes, publishers need to be mindful of size limitations.

The publication of a DER under a domain name indicates protection for that name under IHL. Protection for IP addresses is accomplished through the use of the DNS reverse zone. If protection under IHL is requested for an IP address, the Requestor MUST:
Obtain a proper IP address delegation Publish a reverse zone mapping the target IP addresses to domain names Requests approval for use of the digital emblem from an Approver for the target domain names

section.title: Digital Emblem Verification
section.t:
Any entity can act as an Observer and verify the existence and validity of a digital emblem associated with a target system. An Observer performs the following tasks:
Perform a DNS lookup for a TXT record associated with the target system. If a TXT record exists, parse it for a DER. Otherwise, terminate process. If a DER exists, extract the nonce, reference, and signature. Otherwise, terminate process. Perform a DNS lookup for the TLSA record associated with the reference. If the TLSA exists, extract the key material. Otherwise, terminate process. Using the retrieved key material, nonce, and target domain name, verify the signature.
If the signature verifies, the target system has protection from the digital emblem. In all other cases, it does not.
